title: Credit, Loans, and Debt
description: The most important module in this course. Credit is a tool — but used wrong, it's a trap. Students learn how credit scores work, why minimum payments are a disaster, the real cost of loans, how amortization shifts over time, and the red flags of predatory lending. Every concept uses actual dollar amounts and real APRs.
goals: Explain what a credit score measures and identify the five factors that affect it
Calculate monthly credit card interest and demonstrate the true cost of minimum payments
Compare loan options using total cost (not just monthly payment) and identify the better deal
Explain how amortization works — why early payments are mostly interest
Identify red flags of predatory lending including payday loans, balloon payments, and pressure tactics
instructionalStrategy: Credit scores: use the 'report card for borrowing' analogy. Show the rate difference: 4% vs 8% on a $20,000 car loan.
Credit card math is the most powerful lesson. Show a $3,000 balance at 22% APR with $60 minimum payments — total paid is ~$7,000+ over 15 years. That shock teaches.
Loan comparison: same car, 3-year vs 6-year loan. Lower monthly payment does not equal better deal. Always calculate total cost.
Amortization: show a 3-4 row snippet from a real amortization table. Payment #1 vs payment #60. The 'aha' is 'I paid $500 but only $150 went to my balance?!'
Predatory lending: calculate the real cost of a $500 payday loan at 400% APR. Compare to credit card and personal loan. Frame as protection, not preaching.

scaffold.title: Understanding Credit Scores
scaffold.content: A credit score is a three-digit number (300-850) that tells lenders how risky it is to lend you money. Think of it as a report card for borrowing. A higher score means lower risk, which means lenders offer you lower interest rates. The most common scoring model is FICO. Your score is built from five factors, each weighted differently.
keyPoints: Credit scores range from 300 (very poor) to 850 (exceptional). Above 740 is generally considered 'very good' and unlocks the best rates.
Payment history (35%): the single biggest factor. Even one missed payment can drop your score 60-100 points. Paying on time every time is the #1 rule.
Amounts owed / credit utilization (30%): how much of your available credit you are using. Using $2,000 of a $10,000 limit = 20% utilization. Under 30% is good; under 10% is excellent.
Length of credit history (15%): how long your accounts have been open. Older accounts help your score. This is why closing your oldest card can hurt.
New credit (10%): how many new accounts or inquiries you have recently. Each hard inquiry (loan application) can lower your score by 5-10 points temporarily.
Credit mix (10%): having different types of credit (credit card, auto loan, mortgage) shows you can manage various accounts. Not a dealbreaker, but it helps.

examples.problem: Marcus has a credit score of 720 and qualifies for a car loan at 5.2% APR. His friend Devon has a score of 580 and qualifies at 11.8% APR. Both want to borrow $15,000 for 48 months. Marcus's monthly payment is $347 and Devon's is $393. How much more does Devon pay in total?
examples.solution:
Step 1: Calculate total cost for each borrower.
Marcus: $347 x 48 payments = $16,656
Devon: $393 x 48 payments = $18,864

Step 2: Find the difference.
$18,864 - $16,656 = $2,208

Devon pays $2,208 MORE for the exact same car, just because of a lower credit score. That 580 vs 720 score difference cost him over two thousand dollars.

examples.problem: Jasmine has a credit score of 680. She has $3,000 in credit card balances on $10,000 total credit limits. She wants to raise her score. Which two actions would have the biggest impact, and why?
examples.solution:
The two biggest score factors are:
1. Payment history (35%) — Jasmine should make sure she never misses a payment. Setting up autopay for at least the minimum guarantees on-time payments.
2. Amounts owed / utilization (30%) — She is using $3,000 of $10,000 = 30% utilization. Paying down to $1,000 would bring her to 10%, which is excellent.

These two factors alone control 65% of her score. Improving both could realistically push her from 680 into the 740+ range over 6-12 months.

problems.question: Lena has a credit score of 750 and qualifies for a mortgage at 6.2% APR. If her score dropped to 620, her rate would be 8.1% APR. On a $200,000 30-year mortgage, the monthly payment at 6.2% is $1,226 and at 8.1% is $1,484. How much more would Lena pay in TOTAL over 30 years with the lower credit score?
hints: Total cost = monthly payment x number of payments. A 30-year mortgage has 360 monthly payments.
At 6.2%: $1,226 x 360 = $441,360. Now calculate the total at 8.1%.
Subtract the two totals to find how much extra the lower score costs.
problems.answer: At 6.2%: $1,226 x 360 = $441,360. At 8.1%: $1,484 x 360 = $534,240. Difference: $534,240 - $441,360 = $92,880. A lower credit score would cost Lena $92,880 more over the life of the mortgage.

problems.question: A borrower has these financial habits: pays all bills on time, carries a $2,000 balance on a $10,000 credit limit, has had credit cards for 8 years, recently opened 2 new store accounts in the past month, and has a credit card plus a car loan. For each of the five FICO factors, rate this borrower as 'strong' or 'needs work' and explain why.
hints: Go through each factor one at a time. Start with payment history (35%).
For utilization, calculate: $2,000 / $10,000 = 20%. Is that good or bad?
Opening 2 new accounts recently affects the 'new credit' category (10%).
problems.answer: Payment history (35%): Strong — pays all bills on time. Amounts owed (30%): Strong — 20% utilization ($2,000 / $10,000) is well under 30%. Length of history (15%): Strong — 8 years is solid. New credit (10%): Needs work — 2 new accounts in one month creates multiple hard inquiries. Credit mix (10%): Strong — has both revolving credit (card) and installment credit (car loan). Overall this is a strong profile with one temporary weak spot.

problems.question: Rank the following actions by their likely negative impact on a credit score, from MOST harmful to LEAST harmful: (A) Opening a new store credit card, (B) Missing a mortgage payment by 60 days, (C) Maxing out a $5,000 credit card, (D) Closing your oldest credit card (open for 12 years).
hints: Think about which FICO factor each action affects, and how heavily that factor is weighted.
Missing a payment hits payment history (35%). Maxing out a card hits utilization (30%).
Closing your oldest card affects length of history (15%). A new account affects new credit (10%).
problems.answer: Most harmful to least harmful: B, C, D, A. (B) Missing a mortgage payment by 60 days — hits payment history (35%), the biggest factor. A 60-day late is a severe derogatory mark. (C) Maxing out a $5,000 card — shoots utilization to 100% on that card, hurting amounts owed (30%). (D) Closing oldest card — reduces average account age, hurting length of history (15%). (A) Opening a new store card — minor hit to new credit (10%), usually only 5-10 points.

problems.question: Tyler has a credit score of 760 and gets a $20,000 auto loan at 4.5% APR for 60 months, monthly payment $373. His coworker Brianna has a 610 score and gets the same loan at 13.9% APR, monthly payment $468. How much more does Brianna pay in total over the life of the loan?
problems.answer: Tyler total: $373 x 60 = $22,380. Brianna total: $468 x 60 = $28,080. Difference: $28,080 - $22,380 = $5,700. Brianna pays $5,700 more for the same car because of her lower credit score.

problems.question: Aisha has a $4,000 balance on a credit card with a $5,000 limit, and a $1,500 balance on a card with a $15,000 limit. What is her overall credit utilization percentage? Is this considered good, fair, or poor?
problems.answer: Total balances: $4,000 + $1,500 = $5,500. Total limits: $5,000 + $15,000 = $20,000. Utilization: $5,500 / $20,000 = 0.275 = 27.5%. This is fair — it is under 30% but not under 10%. Paying down the first card would help the most since it is at 80% utilization on its own.

scaffold.title: Credit Card Math — APR, Interest, and the Minimum Payment Trap
scaffold.content: Credit cards charge interest on any balance you carry past the due date. The rate is expressed as an APR (Annual Percentage Rate), but interest is calculated monthly. The formula is simple: Monthly Interest = (APR / 12) x Balance. The trap is minimum payments — they are designed to keep you in debt as long as possible. Most of your minimum payment goes to interest, and only a tiny sliver reduces your actual balance.
keyPoints: APR stands for Annual Percentage Rate. Typical credit card APRs range from 18% to 25%. To get the monthly rate, divide APR by 12.
Monthly interest formula: Monthly Interest = (APR / 12) x Current Balance. Example: 24% APR on $1,000 = (0.24 / 12) x $1,000 = 0.02 x $1,000 = $20 per month.
Minimum payments are usually 1-3% of the balance or a flat amount like $25-$35. They are intentionally low to maximize interest revenue for the bank.

The minimum payment trap: on a $3,000 balance at 22% APR with a $60 minimum payment, about $55 goes to interest and only $5 goes to principal. At that rate, payoff takes 15+ years and you pay over $7,000 total on a $3,000 purchase.
Payoff strategy: always pay MORE than the minimum. Even an extra $50/month can cut payoff time from 15 years to under 3 years.
If you pay your full statement balance by the due date every month, you pay ZERO interest. This is how credit cards should be used.

examples.problem: You have a credit card balance of $2,400 at 21% APR. What is your monthly interest rate, and how much interest will you be charged this month?
examples.solution:
Step 1: Find the monthly rate.
Monthly rate = APR / 12 = 21% / 12 = 1.75%

Step 2: Calculate monthly interest.
Monthly interest = 1.75% x $2,400 = 0.0175 x $2,400 = $42.00

You will be charged $42.00 in interest this month. If your minimum payment is $48, only $6 goes toward your actual balance.

examples.problem: Your credit card balance is $3,000 at 22% APR. Your minimum payment is $60. How much of your first minimum payment goes to interest vs. principal? At this pace, will you pay off the card in 5 years, 10 years, or 15+ years?
examples.solution:
Step 1: Monthly rate = 22% / 12 = 1.833%

Step 2: Month 1 interest = 1.833% x $3,000 = 0.01833 x $3,000 = $55.00

Step 3: Principal paid = Payment - Interest = $60 - $55 = $5.00

So out of your $60 payment, $55 goes straight to the bank as interest. Only $5 actually reduces your balance. Your new balance is $2,995 — you barely made a dent.

At this pace: $3,000 / $5 per month = 600 months = 50 years if the balance never shrank further. In reality, because the balance drops slightly each month, it takes about 15+ years and you pay roughly $7,200 total on a $3,000 purchase. The interest more than doubles the original cost.

examples.problem: Compare two payoff strategies for a $1,800 balance at 20% APR. Strategy A: pay the $45 minimum. Strategy B: pay $150 per month. What happens in month 1 for each?
examples.solution:
Monthly rate = 20% / 12 = 1.667%
Month 1 interest (same for both) = 1.667% x $1,800 = 0.01667 x $1,800 = $30.00

Strategy A ($45 minimum):
Principal paid = $45 - $30 = $15.00
New balance = $1,800 - $15 = $1,785

Strategy B ($150 per month):
Principal paid = $150 - $30 = $120.00
New balance = $1,800 - $120 = $1,680

Strategy B knocks out 8x more principal in the very first month ($120 vs $15). Strategy A would take about 5 years to pay off. Strategy B would take about 13 months. The total interest paid under Strategy A is roughly $700. Under Strategy B, roughly $150.

problems.question: A credit card has a balance of $4,500 at 24% APR. Calculate the monthly interest rate and the interest charge for this month.
hints: Monthly rate = APR / 12. So 24% / 12 = ?
Monthly interest = monthly rate x balance = 2% x $4,500.
problems.answer: Monthly rate = 24% / 12 = 2%. Monthly interest = 2% x $4,500 = 0.02 x $4,500 = $90.00. The card is charged $90.00 in interest this month.

problems.question: Your credit card balance is $2,000 at 18% APR. Your minimum payment is $40. How much of the first payment goes to interest? How much goes to reducing the balance (principal)?
hints: First find the monthly rate: 18% / 12 = 1.5%.
Monthly interest = 1.5% x $2,000 = $30.00.
Principal = total payment minus interest.
problems.answer: Monthly rate = 18% / 12 = 1.5%. Interest = 1.5% x $2,000 = $30.00. Principal = $40 - $30 = $10.00. So $30 goes to interest and only $10 actually reduces the balance. That is 75% interest and 25% principal.

problems.question: You owe $5,000 on a credit card at 19.99% APR. You can pay either $100/month or $250/month. In the first month, how much more principal does the $250 payment cover compared to the $100 payment?
hints: Monthly rate = 19.99% / 12 = approximately 1.666%.
Monthly interest = 1.666% x $5,000 = approximately $83.29.
Calculate principal for each payment amount, then find the difference.
problems.answer: Monthly rate = 19.99% / 12 = 1.666%. Interest = 1.666% x $5,000 = $83.29. At $100/month: principal = $100 - $83.29 = $16.71. At $250/month: principal = $250 - $83.29 = $166.71. Difference: $166.71 - $16.71 = $150.00. The $250 payment covers $150 more in principal. The $100 payment barely touches the balance.

problems.question: A student has a $1,200 credit card balance at 22% APR. Calculate the monthly interest charge.

Jordan has a $3,500 balance on a credit card with 20% APR. His minimum payment is $70. How much of the first payment goes to interest, and how much goes to principal? What is his new balance after the payment?

Nina owes $6,000 at 24% APR. She is deciding between paying the $120 minimum or paying $300 per month. Calculate the interest and principal for month 1 under each strategy. How many times more principal does the $300 payment cover?
problems.answer: Monthly rate = 24% / 12 = 2%. Interest = 2% x $6,000 = $120.00. At $120 minimum: principal = $120 - $120 = $0.00 — the entire payment goes to interest and the balance does not decrease at all. At $300: principal = $300 - $120 = $180.00. The $300 payment covers infinitely more principal because the minimum payment covers zero. This is the minimum payment trap in its worst form.

scaffold.title: Loan Basics — Principal, Rate, Term, and Total Cost
scaffold.content: When you borrow money — for a car, college, or anything else — you repay the original amount (principal) plus interest. Three numbers define every loan: the principal (how much you borrow), the interest rate (APR), and the term (how long you take to repay). The key insight: a lower monthly payment does NOT mean a better deal. You must always compare loans by total cost, which is the monthly payment multiplied by the number of payments.
keyPoints: Principal: the amount borrowed. A $20,000 car loan has a $20,000 principal.
Interest rate (APR): the annual cost of borrowing. Lower is better. Rates depend on your credit score, the loan type, and market conditions.
Term: how many months (or years) you have to repay. Common terms: 36, 48, 60, or 72 months for auto loans; 15 or 30 years for mortgages.
Total cost = monthly payment x number of payments. This is the REAL price of the loan. Always calculate this before signing.
Longer terms mean lower monthly payments BUT higher total cost. A 72-month car loan looks cheaper per month, but you pay thousands more in interest than a 48-month loan.
When comparing two loan offers, the one with the lower total cost is the better deal — even if its monthly payment is higher.

examples.problem: Two dealerships offer the same $22,000 car. Dealer A: 4.9% APR for 48 months, monthly payment $506. Dealer B: 6.5% APR for 72 months, monthly payment $370. Which deal costs less in total?
examples.solution:
Step 1: Calculate total cost for each.
Dealer A: $506 x 48 = $24,288
Dealer B: $370 x 72 = $26,640

Step 2: Compare.
$26,640 - $24,288 = $2,352

Dealer A costs $2,352 LESS even though the monthly payment is $136 higher. The shorter term and lower rate save real money. Dealer B's 'affordable' $370/month actually costs $4,640 in interest ($26,640 - $22,000), while Dealer A's interest is $2,288.

examples.problem: Samira needs a $10,000 personal loan. Bank A: 7.5% for 36 months, $311/month. Bank B: 10.2% for 60 months, $213/month. Which costs less overall, and by how much?
examples.solution:
Bank A total: $311 x 36 = $11,196
Bank B total: $213 x 60 = $12,780

Bank A saves: $12,780 - $11,196 = $1,584

Bank A is the better deal by $1,584. Bank B charges more interest ($2,780 vs $1,196) because of the higher rate AND longer term. The lower monthly payment is a trap — it just stretches the pain over more months.

problems.question: A student borrows $8,000 for a used car at 6.0% APR for 36 months with a monthly payment of $243. What is the total amount paid over the life of the loan? How much of that total is interest?
hints: Total cost = monthly payment x number of payments = $243 x 36.
Interest = total cost - principal (the original amount borrowed).
problems.answer: Total paid = $243 x 36 = $8,748. Interest = $8,748 - $8,000 = $748. The student pays $748 in interest on an $8,000 loan.

problems.question: Maria is comparing two offers for a $20,000 car loan. Offer 1: 3.9% APR for 48 months, payment $451. Offer 2: 0% APR for 60 months, but the sale price increases to $22,000 (no discount), payment $367. Which offer has the lower total cost?
hints: Offer 1 total = $451 x 48. Offer 2 total = $367 x 60.
Be careful — the 0% APR sounds great, but the price of the car went up by $2,000.
Compare the two totals. The lower one is the better deal.
problems.answer: Offer 1: $451 x 48 = $21,648. Offer 2: $367 x 60 = $22,020. Offer 1 is the better deal by $372. The '0% APR' offer hides extra cost in the higher sticker price. Always calculate total cost — marketing can be misleading.

problems.question: Loan A: $15,000 at 5.0% for 48 months, payment $345. Loan B: $15,000 at 5.0% for 60 months, payment $283. Calculate the total cost of each loan. Which is the better deal and by how much?
problems.answer: Loan A: $345 x 48 = $16,560. Loan B: $283 x 60 = $16,980. Loan A costs $420 less. Same rate, but the shorter term means less time for interest to accumulate.

problems.question: Carlos borrows $12,000 for a car at 8.5% APR for 60 months. His monthly payment is $246. What is the total cost of the loan, and how much total interest will he pay?
problems.answer: Total cost = $246 x 60 = $14,760. Total interest = $14,760 - $12,000 = $2,760. Carlos pays $2,760 in interest over five years.

problems.question: Two banks offer Rachel a $25,000 car loan. First National: 4.2% for 48 months, $566/month. Community Credit Union: 3.8% for 60 months, $459/month. Which loan has the lower total cost?
problems.answer: First National: $566 x 48 = $27,168. Community CU: $459 x 60 = $27,540. First National costs $372 less in total, even though the monthly payment is $107 higher. The shorter term wins again.

scaffold.title: How Amortization Works
scaffold.content: Amortization is the process of paying off a loan through regular payments over time. The critical insight is that each payment is split between interest and principal — and that split changes dramatically over the life of the loan. Early payments are mostly interest. Late payments are mostly principal. This is why it feels like you are barely making progress in the first few years of a mortgage.
keyPoints: Every loan payment has two parts: the interest portion (what you pay the bank for borrowing) and the principal portion (what actually reduces your balance).
In early payments, interest is high because the balance is large. Example: on a $180,000 mortgage at 6%, payment #1 is $1,079 — but $900 goes to interest and only $179 goes to principal.
In later payments, interest is lower because the balance has shrunk. The same $1,079 payment sends more and more toward principal as months go by.
An amortization table shows the breakdown for every payment: payment number, interest portion, principal portion, and remaining balance.
Extra payments go entirely toward principal (since your scheduled interest is already covered). Even $50-$100 extra per month can save tens of thousands in interest and years off a mortgage.
This is why refinancing to a lower rate or making extra payments early in the loan saves the most money — you reduce the balance while interest has the biggest impact.

examples.problem:
Here is a snippet from an amortization table for a $180,000 mortgage at 6% APR for 30 years (monthly payment: $1,079.19).

Payment #1: Interest $900.00 | Principal $179.19 | Balance $179,820.81
Payment #2: Interest $899.10 | Principal $180.09 | Balance $179,640.72

What percentage of payment #1 goes to interest? What percentage goes to principal?
examples.solution:
Interest percentage = $900.00 / $1,079.19 = 0.834 = 83.4%
Principal percentage = $179.19 / $1,079.19 = 0.166 = 16.6%

So 83.4% of your first payment goes straight to the bank as interest. Only 16.6% — less than one-sixth — actually pays down your loan. You paid $1,079.19 but your balance only dropped by $179.19. This is the 'aha moment' of amortization.

examples.problem:
Same mortgage. Here are payments at different points in the loan:

Payment #1: Interest $900.00 | Principal $179.19
Payment #180 (year 15): Interest $631.00 | Principal $448.19
Payment #300 (year 25): Interest $269.00 | Principal $810.19

Describe how the interest-to-principal split changes over time.
examples.solution:
Payment #1: $900 interest vs $179 principal — interest is 5x larger than principal.
Payment #180: $631 interest vs $448 principal — interest is still larger, but the gap is closing.
Payment #300: $269 interest vs $810 principal — principal is now 3x larger than interest.

The pattern: early on, most of your payment feeds the bank. Over time, the split reverses. By year 25, over 75% of each payment goes to reducing your balance. This is why the first 5 years of a mortgage feel like you are treading water.

examples.problem: A homeowner has the $180,000 mortgage above. She decides to pay an extra $200/month starting from month 1. The original payoff is 30 years (360 payments) with a total cost of $388,508. With the extra $200/month, the loan pays off in about 22 years (264 payments) with a total cost of $337,782. How much does she save?
examples.solution:
Payments saved: 360 - 264 = 96 payments = 8 years
Money saved: $388,508 - $337,782 = $50,726

By paying $200 extra per month, she saves $50,726 and gets out of debt 8 years early. The extra payments go directly to principal, which reduces the balance faster, which reduces future interest charges. It is a snowball effect.

problems.question: A $150,000 mortgage at 5.5% for 30 years has a monthly payment of $851.68. Payment #1 breakdown: Interest = $687.50, Principal = $164.18. How much of the balance is paid off after the first payment? What percentage of the payment went to reducing the loan?
hints: The principal portion IS the amount that reduces the balance.
Percentage to principal = principal / total payment x 100.
problems.answer: $164.18 is paid off the balance after the first payment. Percentage to principal = $164.18 / $851.68 = 0.193 = 19.3%. Only 19.3% of the payment reduced the loan. The other 80.7% ($687.50) went to interest.

problems.question: A homeowner has a $200,000 mortgage at 6.5% for 30 years, monthly payment $1,264.14. After making payments for 10 years (120 payments), the remaining balance is $175,868. How much total has the homeowner paid over 10 years? How much of the original $200,000 principal has been paid off? How much went to interest?
hints: Total paid = monthly payment x number of payments made so far.
Principal paid off = original balance - remaining balance.
Interest paid = total paid - principal paid off.
problems.answer: Total paid = $1,264.14 x 120 = $151,696.80. Principal paid off = $200,000 - $175,868 = $24,132. Interest paid = $151,696.80 - $24,132 = $127,564.80. After 10 years and over $151,000 in payments, only $24,132 (about 12%) of the original loan has been paid off. The remaining $127,565 went to interest.

problems.question: A $220,000 mortgage at 7% for 30 years has a monthly payment of $1,463.16. In payment #1, interest = $1,283.33 and principal = $179.83. What percentage of payment #1 goes to interest? What percentage goes to principal?
problems.answer: Interest percentage = $1,283.33 / $1,463.16 = 87.7%. Principal percentage = $179.83 / $1,463.16 = 12.3%. Only 12.3% of the first payment reduces the balance.

problems.question: A borrower has a $160,000 mortgage at 6% for 30 years, monthly payment $959.28. She pays an extra $100/month starting from payment #1, making each payment $1,059.28. With the extra payments, the loan is paid off in approximately 25 years (300 payments) instead of 30 years (360 payments). Calculate the total cost under each scenario and the savings.
problems.answer: Original total: $959.28 x 360 = $345,340.80. With extra payments: $1,059.28 x 300 = $317,784.00. Savings: $345,340.80 - $317,784.00 = $27,556.80. She saves about $27,557 and pays off the loan 5 years early by adding just $100/month.

problems.question: Look at these two payments from the same 30-year mortgage. Payment #12 (year 1): Interest $880, Principal $195. Payment #240 (year 20): Interest $490, Principal $585. For each payment, calculate what percentage goes to principal. What does this tell you about how amortization works?
problems.answer: Payment #12: principal % = $195 / ($880 + $195) = $195 / $1,075 = 18.1%. Payment #240: principal % = $585 / ($490 + $585) = $585 / $1,075 = 54.4%. In year 1, only 18% of the payment reduces the balance. By year 20, over 54% goes to principal. Amortization gradually shifts the split from mostly-interest to mostly-principal over the life of the loan.

scaffold.title: Predatory Lending — Red Flags and Real Costs
scaffold.content: Predatory lending means offering loan terms designed to trap borrowers in debt. It targets people who are desperate, have low credit scores, or do not fully understand the terms. The most common form is payday loans, which charge fees equivalent to 400%+ APR. Knowing the red flags protects you from financial harm.
keyPoints: Payday loans: short-term (usually 14 days), small-dollar loans with fees of $15-$20 per $100 borrowed. That translates to approximately 400-520% APR. Borrowers often cannot repay on time and 're-roll' the loan, paying the fee again and again.
Red flag #1: 'Guaranteed approval' or 'No credit check needed.' Legitimate lenders always assess your ability to repay. If they do not check, they profit whether you can repay or not.
Red flag #2: Pressure to sign immediately. 'This offer expires today!' or 'Just sign — do not worry about the details.' Legitimate lenders give you time to review terms.
Red flag #3: No clear disclosure of APR or total cost. If the lender only talks about the 'fee' ($15 per $100) and never mentions the APR, they are hiding the true cost.
Balloon payments: a loan with low monthly payments but a massive lump sum due at the end. If you cannot pay the balloon, you must refinance (often at worse terms) or lose the asset.
Alternatives to predatory loans: credit union personal loans (8-18% APR), payment plans with creditors, community assistance programs, borrowing from family with a written agreement.

examples.problem: A payday lender offers a $500 loan with a $75 fee due in 14 days. What is the cost per dollar borrowed? What is the approximate APR? Use the formula: APR = (fee / principal) x (365 / loan term in days) x 100.
examples.solution:
Step 1: Cost per dollar = $75 / $500 = $0.15 (15 cents per dollar borrowed)

Step 2: APR = ($75 / $500) x (365 / 14) x 100
= 0.15 x 26.07 x 100
= 391%

The APR is approximately 391%. For comparison, even a high-rate credit card is 24-29% APR. This payday loan charges more than 13x the interest rate of a credit card.

examples.problem: Compare the cost of borrowing $500 through three different options for an emergency. Option A: Payday loan, $75 fee, due in 14 days. Option B: Credit card cash advance at 24% APR, repaid in 30 days. Option C: Credit union personal loan at 12% APR, repaid over 6 months at $86/month.
examples.solution:
Option A (Payday loan): Cost = $75 fee. Total repaid = $575.

Option B (Credit card advance): Monthly rate = 24% / 12 = 2%. Interest for one month = 2% x $500 = $10.00. Total repaid = $510.

Option C (Credit union loan): Total = $86 x 6 = $516. Interest = $516 - $500 = $16.00.

Comparison:
Payday loan: $75 cost
Credit card: $10 cost
Credit union: $16 cost

The payday loan costs 7.5x more than the credit card and nearly 5x more than the personal loan. Even a credit card cash advance — normally considered expensive — is dramatically cheaper than a payday loan.

examples.problem: A car dealership offers a loan with monthly payments of $199 for 60 months, plus a balloon payment of $8,000 due at the end. The car costs $18,000. What is the total amount paid? How does it compare to the car's price?
examples.solution:
Step 1: Regular payments = $199 x 60 = $11,940

Step 2: Add balloon payment: $11,940 + $8,000 = $19,940

Step 3: Compare to price: $19,940 - $18,000 = $1,940 in interest/fees

Total paid = $19,940. That is $1,940 more than the car's value. The low $199 monthly payment hides the $8,000 surprise at the end. If the buyer cannot come up with $8,000 in month 60, they face repossession or must refinance at even worse terms. This is a textbook predatory structure.

problems.question: A payday lender charges $20 per $100 borrowed on a 14-day loan. If you borrow $400, what is the total fee? What is the approximate APR? Use: APR = (fee / principal) x (365 / loan term in days) x 100.
hints: $20 per $100 means for $400 you pay $20 x 4.
APR formula: plug in fee, principal ($400), and term (14 days).
Divide 365 by 14 to get the annualizing factor.
problems.answer: Fee = $20 x 4 = $80. APR = ($80 / $400) x (365 / 14) x 100 = 0.20 x 26.07 x 100 = 521%. The APR is approximately 521%. That is more than 20x a typical credit card rate.

problems.question: Identify the red flags in this advertisement: 'GUARANTEED APPROVAL! No credit check needed! Get $1,000 cash TODAY! Do not worry about the fine print — just sign and drive!' List at least three warning signs and explain why each is dangerous.
hints: Look for promises that sound too good to be true.
Think about why a legitimate lender would always check your credit.
Why would a lender tell you NOT to read the terms?
problems.answer: Red flags: (1) 'Guaranteed approval' with 'no credit check' — legitimate lenders must assess ability to repay; skipping this means the lender profits regardless of whether you can afford the loan. (2) 'Get $1,000 TODAY' — pressure to act immediately without researching alternatives or reading terms. (3) 'Do not worry about the fine print' — actively discouraging the borrower from understanding costs, fees, and penalties. (4) No mention of APR, interest rate, or total repayment cost anywhere in the ad. Any one of these is a warning sign; all four together is a textbook predatory offer.

A used car lot offers this deal: $175/month for 48 months with a $5,500 balloon payment at the end. The car is listed at $12,500. What is the total cost? How much more than the list price do you end up paying?
problems.answer: Regular payments = $175 x 48 = $8,400. Total with balloon = $8,400 + $5,500 = $13,900. Amount over list price = $13,900 - $12,500 = $1,400. You pay $1,400 more than the car's price, and you need $5,500 cash in month 48 or you risk losing the car.

problems.question: Maya needs $600 for an emergency car repair. She has three options. Option A: Payday loan, $90 fee, due in 14 days. Option B: Credit card at 22% APR, pay back in full next month (30 days). Option C: Borrow from her credit union at 10% APR, repay over 4 months at $153/month. Calculate the cost of each option and rank them from cheapest to most expensive.
problems.answer: Option A: Cost = $90. Option B: Monthly rate = 22% / 12 = 1.833%. Interest = 1.833% x $600 = $11.00. Cost = $11. Option C: Total = $153 x 4 = $612. Cost = $612 - $600 = $12. Ranking cheapest to most expensive: Option B ($11), Option C ($12), Option A ($90). The payday loan costs more than 8x the next most expensive option.
